instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message:
Have a computer that works until it sleeps, then never wakes up. I have to reset SMC to make it power on again. 
Totally have no clue how to begin. 
Need to resurrect it! :-)

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message: Historyof this computer???, it was dropped, water, anything??

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message:
Minor water damage near display port, no evidence of dropping. Seems to work normal as long as it does not sleep. Once it sleeps then has to have reset to start again
Have the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> rail present with charger plugged in. Can be shut off and turned back on, just not from sleep mode

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message: water damage near displayport means it seeped into the SMC as well. I'd give it a light reflow with flux to get rid of corrosion, if that doesn't work a reball, if that doesn't do it a replacement.

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message: what temperature on hot air to reflow and approximately how long?

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message: when I set my JBC to 450c it heats to 510, when i set my weller to 500c it heats to 425.. i have no fucking idea what to tell you for temperature. these stations are all pieces of shit that do what they want. put flux around it, heat from far away, and you will see this puddle of flux slowly "disappear" until there is only flux sitting around the chip for 1mm outside of it on every side. once at that point you can go in around the chip until you get a reflow. practice on something else before doing this on a fixable board.

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message:
Ok, thanks. Will do., Just curious though, the smc is on the complete opposite end of the board, why would you think liquid would have got there? there are no signs of liquid anywhere around it. I am just trying to be cautious before i try to reflow the SMC. ( i have never done it before and replacing it is not an option for me as I do not have the equipment)
The display connector got hit and there was a little liquid around the thunderbolt area(<CHIP>U2800</CHIP>).
I have inspected the rest of the board and have not found any other signs of liquid.

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message:
OK, reflowed the smc, now i have no green or orange light and does not turn on at all. Have     [SIZE=12px][FONT=Courier]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, [/FONT][/SIZE][FONT=Courier]PPVIN S5 HS[SIZE=9px], [/SIZE]<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>,[/FONT][FONT=Courier]<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> [/FONT]

[FONT=Courier]Am i to assume i killed the SMC?[/FONT]

[FONT=Courier]â€‹I used to have a working computer that would not come out of sleep, now I have one that won't turn on at all![/FONT]

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message: Now you need to pull the SMC and reball it or it may totally be fried.....

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message:
When reflowing SMC, remove edge bonding! You can't reflow a chip that still has the edge bonding.

Now it turns on but must figure out this sleep sensor crap.

threads.title: 2014 15" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sleeps and never wakes up
threads.message: So I missed a little edge bonding....:o:o:o:o
